Not only do these hurt UX, but Google penalizes mobile pages that show intrusive interstitials. Our landing page likely won’t have any by design, since the goal is conversion (perhaps a thank-you modal after conversion, which is fine). If you ever consider using exit-intent popups or such, note that on mobile exit-intent is tricky and often translates to something intrusive. It’s generally safer to avoid them.
Optimize Font and Button Sizes: As mentioned, make sure text is large enough on mobile. Also consider line-height (spacing between lines) – slightly larger line-height (say 1.5em) improves readability of paragraphs on small screens. Buttons and form inputs should use a legible font size too. Often a problem on mobile is some desktop styles make text tiny on mobile; to counteract that, using relative fonts (like using viewport width units or percentages) can help scale text appropriately. We want to avoid the need for the user to zoom in.
Testing on Real Devices: It’s vital to test the landing page on actual phones and tablets. Emulators in a browser are a start, but real devices can reveal issues (like an element that is off-screen or a fixed element that doesn’t behave correctly). Check both iOS and Android if possible, and multiple browsers (Chrome, Safari). Also test various screen sizes – e.g., older smaller phones vs newer big phones – to ensure the design adapts (the responsive breakpoints might need tweaking if something looks off at a certain size).
Mobile-Specific Adjustments: Sometimes you might hide or swap out certain elements on mobile to streamline the experience. For example, a large image that looks great on desktop might be too small to be useful on mobile or push important text too far down. You could choose to hide that image on mobile for a better flow, or use a simpler image. Ensure headings don’t occupy too many lines on a narrow screen – if a headline is long, you might use a slightly smaller font on mobile or shorten the copy for mobile via CSS (advanced, but sometimes done). The key is the core message remains the same and nothing essential is lost for mobile users. Everything we planned (headline, benefits, CTA, proof) should still be present on mobile, just arranged vertically.
Touch Gestures and Mobile Behavior: If using any carousels (like for testimonials or images), ensure they support swipe gestures on mobile – users should be able to swipe left/right to navigate, not just rely on tiny arrow buttons. Also consider disabling any hover effects for mobile (since hover doesn’t exist on touch screens) and making sure clickable areas are obvious (maybe add subtle underlines on text links on mobile if color alone might not indicate it’s a link). Basically, test that any interactive element works with taps/swipes.
By following these mobile-first best practices, the landing page will provide a smooth experience on small screens. Remember, many busy entrepreneurs might click an ad or email on their phone first. If the mobile experience is poor, they’ll drop off and we lose the lead. But if it’s seamless – fast, easy to read, easy to act – we capture their interest on the spot. Additionally, a great mobile page bolsters our SEO (as Google prioritizes mobile-friendly sites). Arzani will benefit from making a strong impression on mobile users, which in turn boosts overall conversion rates.
CTA Optimization Techniques
The Call to Action (CTA) is the conversion keystone of the landing page. We need to make it as compelling and frictionless as possible for visitors to click that “Get a free valuation” button. We’ve touched on CTA copy and design; here we’ll summarize and add techniques specifically to optimize the CTA for maximum conversions:
Singular, Prominent CTA: As emphasized, stick to one primary CTA action on the page – Get a free valuation. While we repeat the button in multiple places (top and bottom), it always does the same thing (initiates the valuation process​
balsamiq.com
】. This consistency avoids confusion. Every CTA instance should be highly visible: use a bright, contrasting color that isn’t heavily used elsewhere on the page (to draw the eye). Also, make sure the CTA button looks like a button – use a rectangular shape with perhaps slightly rounded corners, and a hover effect on desktop (e.g., a slight darken or shadow on hover) to signal interactivit​
balsamiq.com
】. On mobile, as mentioned, consider a sticky CTA that’s always at hand.
CTA Copy – Clarity and Value: The wording on the CTA should combine an action verb with a value proposition. “Get My Free Valuation” is effective because it’s action-oriented (“Get”), personalized (“My”), and highlights the value (“Free Valuation”). Using first-person (“My”) in CTA copy is a known technique that can increase clicks because it subconsciously makes the user envision the result as theirs (e.g., Copyhackers found first-person CTAs often perform well). We could test variants like “Get Your Free Valuation” vs “Get My Free Valuation” – but starting with first-person is a good bet. Also ensure it’s not too wordy – 2-5 words is ideal for button text. It should convey what happens next; avoid generic “Submit” or “Continue”, which are weak. “Get Free Valuation” tells them exactly what they’re getting by clicking.
Visual Emphasis and Isolation: Surround the CTA with whitespace or an encapsulating design to make it stand ou​
balsamiq.com
】. For example, in the hero, if the CTA is below the subheadline, make sure there’s sufficient padding around it so it doesn’t get lost. In the final section, we might put the CTA on its own line with a minimal text around. This isolation effect draws attention. Also, use an arrow icon or chevron on the button if appropriate (like “→” or a right-pointing arrow graphic after the text) to give a visual cue of forward movement. It’s not necessary, but sometimes can subtly increase click rates (it indicates “this will take you somewhere”).
Size and Placement: The CTA buttons should be big enough to notice easily. A good rule is that the main CTA should be one of the largest elements on the screen after the headline. It shouldn’t be so large that it looks obnoxious, but it should be larger than any secondary buttons (if we had any, which we don’t) or form fields. Placement wise, we have one CTA early (likely right below hero text or integrated into hero) and one at the end. Additionally, a CTA can be repeated after a persuasive section – for instance, after the benefits or after social proof, we could include a text link or another button (“Ready to get your valuation? Click here”) leading to the form. Balsamiq suggests you may include the button multiple times if the page is long, at logical break​
balsamiq.com
】. For Arzani’s page, two times (top and bottom) is probably sufficient, given it’s not extremely long-form. But ensure the bottom CTA is immediately visible when a user finishes reading; they shouldn’t have to scroll back up to ac​
balsamiq.com
】.
Microcopy to Reduce Anxiety: Near the CTA, include a brief note that eases concerns. We did this with phrases like “fast, free, and 100% confidential” under the button. Other effective microcopy could be: “No credit card needed,” “No obligations,” or “Takes less than 2 minutes.” These address fears that clicking will lead to a tedious or costly process. For example, if someone worries “Will I have to fill a huge form?”, seeing “takes 2 minutes” sets their mind at ease. Or if they worry “Is this really free?”, the word “free” on the button and a reiteration below cover that. Another example: “We’ll provide your valuation with no strings attached.” This kind of microcopy builds trust right at the point of conversion.
Urgency and Timing Cues: To prompt immediate action, you can introduce urgency in the CTA or surrounding text (but carefully). For instance, the CTA could say “Get My Free Valuation Now”. Adding “now” or “today” can psychologically nudge faster action. If Arzani ever decides to make the free valuation a limited-time offer, that could be potent: e.g., “Get My Free Valuation (Limited Offer)” or a countdown indicating “Offer ends in 5 days” (though that would need a dynamic component or at least to be managed so it’s truthful). Even without a literal deadline, you can create a sense of urgency by emphasizing opportunity cost: “Get My Free Valuation and seize the market” – not typical on a button, but maybe in surrounding text like “Don’t miss out on this month’s active buyers – know your value now.” In our context, a gentle urgency (“now”) is likely enough, since pressing too hard might seem gimmicky in B2B. We can also rely on FOMO by hints like “Join dozens of business owners who’ve already valued their business this week” near the CTA if that data is available.
Testing CTA Variations: Optimize the CTA through A/B testing (more on that later) – but a quick note: test things like button color, copy text, and even shape. For example, perhaps a green button vs. an orange button could yield a better result – it often depends on what draws the eye given the rest of the color scheme. The good news is that because our page will have a singular focus, any color that isn’t used elsewhere will naturally stand out. Arzani’s brand palette might dictate the best choice (e.g., if their logo is blue, a complementary color like orange might stand out). Many studies show that contrasting color is more critical than any one “magic” color (there’s no universally best CTA color, it’s context-dependent). The key is consistency: pick a CTA color and use it for all primary buttons so users know that’s the action color.
Avoiding Distractions at CTA Click: Make sure that when the user clicks the CTA, the experience is smooth. If the CTA is a button that jumps to a form section, ensure it actually scrolls or opens correctly. If it opens a sign-up modal, the modal should load quickly and have the form ready. If it goes to another page, that page must be laser-focused too (ideally, we’d keep it on one page or a modal to not lose them). Essentially, the CTA’s effect should be immediate and on-point. Also, disable any unnecessary links near CTAs (for example, sometimes people put social media share buttons on landing pages – don’t do that, it tempts users to leave the page; we haven’t included any such things).
Use of Trust Badges Near CTA: Another optimization is placing a small trust symbol near the CTA. For example, a padlock icon with “Secure & confidential” (we mentioned), or a BBB accreditation logo if applicable, or even something like “★ 4.9/5 TrustScore” from reviews if Arzani had that. These can reassure right at the decision point. We just have to keep them subtle and in service of the CTA, not competing with it visually.
CTA in Email Follow-ups: Slightly tangential, but if someone leaves without converting, Arzani might retarget or email them (if we captured email via partial form). The landing page CTA optimization also extends to those follow-ups – e.g., email subject lines like “Don’t forget your free valuation” and in the email, a big CTA button to return. This is more about funnel strategy, but worth noting that the same principles (clear, compelling CTA) apply in any re-engagement.
In summary, our CTA strategy is: make it obvious, make it appealing, make it easy. “Obvious” through standout design and isolation, “appealing” through compelling copy (“free valuation” is inherently appealing to our audience) and urgency, and “easy” through minimizing steps and assuring them it’s simple/quick. By refining these aspects and continually testing improvements (CTA text and design are among the easiest high-impact tests to run), we can steadily boost the conversion rate of the page.
Social Proof and Credibility Elements
Trust is a deciding factor in converting B2B leads. We’ve already incorporated social proof in our content; here we’ll focus on how to maximize its impact through placement and variety of credibility elements:
Diverse Forms of Social Proof: We should include at least two or more types of social proof on the pag​
balsamiq.com
】:
Testimonials/Reviews: We have customer quotes which are extremely persuasive because they tell a story of success. Make sure these testimonials are attributed with name, perhaps business name or location, and a photo if possible. A face next to a quote adds authenticity. If a user sees “Sold my cafe in 4 months thanks to Arzani’s valuation – highly recommend!” – Jane D., Cafe Owner (London) with Jane’s smiling face, it humanizes our service and builds trust. Consider using a slider if space is tight, but also know that many users might not scroll a carousel – so it might be better to show 2-3 testimonials all at once in a column or grid. Each testimonial should hit a different angle if possible (one about fast sale, one about good price, one about ease of process) to cover multiple concerns.
Logos of Clients/Partners: If Arzani has notable businesses that have been bought/sold through the platform, show their logos in a “Trusted by” section. Even if the businesses aren’t widely famous, the presence of logos implies “real companies use this.” For example, logos of a few small business brands or franchises will do. If no client logos, consider logos of media outlets or awards: e.g., if Arzani was mentioned in TechCrunch or The Telegraph, putting “As seen in [TechCrunch logo] [TechNation logo] etc.” can add huge credibility. Industry affiliations can also go here (like partner networks, or if Arzani is part of an incubator or has investors, their logos with a caption “Backed by…”). Logos work best typically in a horizontal row or grid, often in grayscale to blend with a professional tone, introduced by a line like “Trusted by businesses and organizations such as:​

】.

1,200+ free valuations delivered to UK business owners.
98% satisfaction rate among Arzani users (if we had survey data or NPS).
50+ businesses sold in the last year via Arzani.
These kind of metrics, if available, should be highlighted. If Arzani is new and numbers are small, we might skip this or focus on growth rate or unique value instead. But since the prompt suggests outperforming Rightbiz, presumably Arzani wants to project strength, so any positive metric helps. Even a small number can be framed positively: e.g., “Join dozens of savvy owners who’ve tried Arzani this month.” It implies momentum.

These lend third-party validation – someone else vouches for Arzani. Leadfeeder suggests using awards or certifications to win trus​

Security/Privacy Seals: While not social proof per se, things like a Norton Secured or GDPR compliant icon can increase trust (especially when users are about to input data). We can place a small lock icon with “GDPR Compliant” near the form submit, as mentioned. It signals that Arzani respects privacy and security – critical for a platform dealing with confidential business info.
Placement of Social Proof: We integrated testimonials in a dedicated section after the solution. That’s good, but also consider sprinkling micro-proof elsewhere:
Perhaps place a short testimonial blurb or a star-rating right under the hero as an immediate trust signal. For example, below the CTA in hero, a small text: “★ ★ ★ ★ ★ Rated 5/5 by business owners like you” (if true) or a rotating one-line testimonial (“‘Arzani made selling my business easy’ – [Name]”). This way, even those who don’t scroll much see a form of social proof right away.
We have a main social proof section with multiple testimonials and logos – that’s great to reinforce mid-page.
Near the final CTA, we could echo a tiny proof element again (like “Join others who have succeeded – 50 businesses sold this year!” near the bottom CTA). That final nudge can reassure right before clicking.
Authenticity and Specificity: The more specific the social proof, the more credible. A testimonial saying “Great service!” is far weaker than one that says “With Arzani, we got 3 offers within a month and sold above asking. I saved £10k by not using a broke​
rightbiz.co.uk
】.” The latter has detail (3 offers, 1 month, £10k saved). Encourage testimonials that mention concrete results or measurable outcomes, as these are convincin​
rightbiz.co.uk
】. Even a quote like “...their careful risk assessments helped me make an informed decision​
arzani.co.uk
】 from the Arzani site’s testimonial is nice and specific to buying decisions. Use such specifics from any existing user feedback (the content we saw in Arzani’s FAQ/testimonials can be repurposed as quotes with permission).
Credibility through Content and Tone: It’s not just explicit social proof that builds credibility – the overall tone and quality of content do as well. Our copy’s professional tone, correct grammar, and helpful information all contribute to the impression that Arzani is a legitimate, expert company. Sloppy copy or design can erode trust. Also, being transparent in the FAQ (like admitting “accuracy ~90%” rather than claiming 100%) ironically increases credibility because it shows honesty. Peep Laja often notes that clarity and honesty beat hype in B2B. So all our credibility elements should feel genuine. If Arzani is new and doesn’t have a lot of customers, it’s better to have one or two real, solid testimonials than five fake-sounding generic ones. Quality over quantity for trust elements.
Leverage Experts and Leadership: Another form of credibility is expert authority. For instance, if Arzani’s founder or team includes notable experts (like “Ex-investment banker” or “Valuation expert with 20 years experience”), that could be subtly mentioned. Perhaps an “About us” blurb or even a quote from the founder: “Our mission is to empower small business owners with AI insights that were once only available to big corporations,” – [Name], Founder of Arzani. This isn’t exactly social proof, but it adds a human face and authority voice. A small photo of the founder with a quote can personalize the brand. However, use this only if it strengthens trust (if the founder has relevant creds or a compelling vision). It shouldn’t distract from the main flow, so maybe as a sidebar or within the FAQ as an answer (“Who are we? We’re a team of X, Y, Z...” briefly).
Case Studies: If time and space permit, a mini-case study could be a powerful credibility booster. It combines story + proof. For example, a short paragraph with a subheading “Success Story: [Business Name]” describing how Arzani helped a specific client, including before/after metrics (like increased sale price or reduced time to sell). End it with that client’s testimonial quote. This can be in the social proof section or in a sidebar. It serves readers who like narrative proof, adding depth beyond one-line quotes.
Third-Party Endorsements: Sometimes, having an industry expert or influencer endorsement can be social proof. E.g., if a known small business consultant or a well-known platform (like a quote from a CEO of a related company or a professor) says something positive about Arzani or its approach (“AI valuations are the future of small business sales” – Dr. So-and-so, Business School). If Arzani has any advisory board or notable backers, mention of that can instill trust (e.g., “Backed by alumni of [prestigious incubator]”). This might be beyond scope, but worth noting as a tactic.
Placement Timing: Make sure by the time a user is considering the CTA, they have encountered some social proof. We wouldn’t want the CTA to appear before any trust has been built. In our layout, hero (CTA) is first, but that’s common – and we ameliorate it by possibly including a micro-proof near it and by quickly following with reasons and proof. As they scroll, they hit social proof mid-way, which should seal trust. And then at the bottom CTA we can remind them of trust (like “Start your free valuation – join others who succeeded”).
Don’t Oversell – Authentic Tone: The credibility elements should feel like testimonials, not advertisements. E.g., use natural language that real customers would use, even if it’s not super polished. A slightly unpolished genuine quote can be more credible than a perfectly phrased one that reads like ad copy. Also, if including any star ratings or such, ensure they match actual reviews somewhere (or state “internal survey” or whatever the source is). Modern audiences are savvy and skeptical; anything that looks too good (all 5-star glowing with zero detail) might ironically reduce trust. Balance praise with realism (for instance, a testimonial might mention they were initially skeptical or had a challenge, which they overcame using Arzani – that actually feels real and thus more persuasive).
Security and Privacy Promises: Since part of credibility is also the safety of using the service, reiterate privacy promises where relevant (we do in FAQ and near CTA). Also, ensure the page uses HTTPS (an SSL certificate) – a “Not secure” browser warning would kill trust immediately. This is basic but worth stating: the landing page must be on a secure URL, especially since users will input data.
By skillfully deploying these social proof and credibility elements, we alleviate the fear of “Is this legit? Will this work for me? Have others had success?” Those are the subconscious questions in a visitor’s mind. After seeing the proof, the hope is the visitor thinks, “Others did it and got great results, the company seems trustworthy and competent – I won’t be the guinea pig. Let’s try this.” That confidence is what tips them into clicking the CTA and becoming a lead.
Conversion-Focused Form Design
Since the primary CTA leads to a form submission (to get a free valuation, likely the user needs to provide some information), the design of that form is crucial for conversion. A poorly designed form can cause drop-offs even after a user clicks “Get My Free Valuation.” Below are best practices to ensure the form is user-friendly and optimized to get that lead info:
Keep the Form Short and Simple: Only ask for the information that is absolutely necessary to start the valuation proces​
cxl.com
】. For a free valuation, that might initially be just a couple of fields: e.g., Business Name, Your Name, Email, Phone (optional). Potentially, you might ask for one key business metric to tailor the valuation (like annual revenue or industry) – but consider if you can avoid that in this first step. Remember, each additional form field can reduce conversion rates (more friction​
cxl.com
】. As Peep Laja notes, a form with 1-3 fields is ideal for lead gen if you can manage i​
cxl.com
】. Perhaps Arzani can generate a basic valuation range with minimal info and then follow up for more details. The initial form should lower the barrier: name and contact might suffice to “lock in” their interest. You can always gather more data later via a follow-up email or call (once the lead is captured).
Multi-Step Form (if needed): If you do need more info for a meaningful valuation (for example, industry, years in business, revenue, profit, etc.), consider a multi-step form rather than one long form. Multi-step forms often convert higher because they don’t overwhelm the user at once. The first step could be just contact info (easy stuff) – once they submit that, step 2 asks business specifics. Many users who complete step 1 will continue (commitment consistency). Also, use a progress indicator (“Step 1 of 2”, “Next: Business Details”) to let them know it’s short. For instance, Step 1: Name & Email; Step 2: 3-4 business questions (perhaps in a conversational tone like “What’s your industry? (dropdown), Approximate annual revenue? (range selection)”). Each step should be on its own screen on mobile to avoid a super long scrolling form.
Inline Form in Hero vs Separate Page: We could place the first part of the form right in the hero section (like an email capture field and button). This can increase conversions for folks ready to get started immediately. For example, a single-field “Enter your email to get started” with the CTA. However, an argument could be made to not show the form until they click the CTA (to not intimidate those who need persuasion first). This is something to test. One approach is: have the CTA button in hero open a lightbox form or scroll to a form section labeled “Get Your Free Valuation.” This way, those who click are showing intent and then see the form. Alternatively, an embedded mini-form (name, email, submit) in the hero can capture quick wins. If doing that, ensure the form is very short (just one or two fields), and you can collect the rest later. For example, “Get my free valuation” in hero could actually be an email field + button. Pressing it either submits and then shows step 2 or at least captures email so if they abandon later, you still got a lead to follow up with.
Form Field Design: Design fields with clear labels. Place labels above the field or inside as placeholders but if using placeholders, ensure that upon focus out the typed text is clearly visible and the user doesn’t forget what the field was. Many modern forms use floating labels (the text moves above as a mini-label when you start typing). That can be nice for saving space and clarity. Use helpful defaults where possible (e.g., a dropdown for industry pre-filled with “Select industry”). Mark optional fields clearly if any (and consider making most fields optional except maybe contact info, to reduce friction – you can follow up to get missing data).
Error Handling and Validation: Implement real-time validation to catch errors before submission. For instance, if the email format is wrong, show a small red hint “Please enter a valid email” as they move off the field. When they hit submit, if something’s missing, highlight the field in red and give a helpful message. Make sure the error messages are in plain language (e.g., “Please fill in your business name” rather than a generic “Field required”). This prevents frustration. Also, ensure that if the user does encounter an error, the form doesn’t wipe all their inputs – nothing is more annoying than filling details, getting an error, and losing everything typed. Always preserve what they entered so they can just correct one field.
Privacy Reassurance: Right below the form or submit button, include a note about privacy. For instance, “💡 Your valuation is confidential. We won’t share your data with anyone.” or “We respect your privacy and will only use your info to provide your valuation.” This is especially important in B2B because owners are protective of their business info. A reassurance can increase their willingness to submit the form. Also provide a link to the privacy policy (could be a small text link “Privacy Policy”) – but have it open in a modal or new tab so they don’t completely navigate awa​
balsamiq.com
】.
Call-to-Action on Submit Button: The submit button on the form should continue the same phrasing: e.g., “Get My Free Valuation” (if it’s the final step) or “Next: See My Valuation” if multi-step. If multi-step, the final step’s button could say “Get My Valuation Report” to indicate this click finishes the process. Make the button full-width on mobile for easy tapping. Also, consider using a contrasting color consistent with earlier CTA buttons.
Loading/Success Feedback: After clicking submit, provide immediate feedback. For example, change the button to a loading spinner or “Submitting…” state so the user knows it’s processing. Then show a thank-you or confirmation message. Possibly, the landing page could then either:
Display a confirmation text in place of the form (e.g., “Thank you! Your valuation is being prepared. We’ll reach out to you at [email].” and perhaps what to expect next).
Or redirect to a dedicated thank-you page with next steps (which could be an opportunity to upsell or provide more info).
The key is to finalize the conversion loop with a positive reinforcement. Even something like “Success! Check your email for your valuation report within X hours” if it’s not instant, or “Success! Our team will contact you within one business day to personally review your valuation.” Setting the expectation manages the relationship going forward.
Minimize Friction and Cognitive Load: Use smart defaults if available. For instance, if the valuation is presumably for UK businesses only (Arzani is UK-based), maybe default country = UK so they don’t have to fill that. If there’s a phone field, pre-format or auto-detect country code. If industry field, provide a dropdown or auto-suggest so they don’t have to type from scratch. Each little convenience helps. Also, avoid asking for information that might be sensitive right off the bat. For example, owners might hesitate to provide detailed financials to an unknown platform through a form. It might be better to get basic contact info and then have an analyst follow up for financial details, or at least reassure them that any detailed info will be handled securely (with NDA if needed). Our form should feel easy and safe to fill.
Accessible Forms: Ensure form fields have proper labels for screen readers. Also, the form should be navigable by keyboard (for accessibility and for power users who prefer keyboard). This also means the focus outline should be visible when tabbing through fields (don’t remove outline in CSS without providing an alternative). While many of Arzani’s users will be sighted and using mouse/touch, catering to all users is part of good practice and sometimes legally required (accessibility).
Mobile Form Considerations: On mobile, when the on-screen keyboard pops up, it can occlude half the screen. Make sure the form is designed such that when you focus a field on mobile, it scrolls into view above the keyboard (so the user isn’t typing blindly). Also keep fields minimal to reduce typing. Possibly integrate device capabilities – e.g., allow voice dictation (that’s more on the user’s side with their keyboard). For phone number, the numeric keypad makes entry easier.
Use of Captcha/Spam Prevention: If the form is publicly accessible, consider how to avoid spam bot submissions (which can pollute leads). A simple Google reCAPTCHA v3 (invisible) can be used, or at least a honeypot field (an invisible field that humans won’t fill but bots might, to filter them). However, don’t use a clunky CAPTCHA that the user has to solve (like image selection) unless spam becomes a problem – those can hurt conversion significantly due to annoyance. Aim for behind-the-scenes solutions.
Form Placement on Landing Page: If we implement as a two-step (CTA then form), the landing page itself might not show the full form until CTA is clicked. If the form is part of the page content (like a separate section or the hero), ensure it’s visually appealing. Often, a form can be placed inside a bordered box or with a slight background shade to stand out. For example, a light grey panel with the form fields, making it clear it’s an input area. Use concise instructional text if needed above the form: e.g., “Get started with your free valuation – just fill out the details below:” This can set context. We had that in the final CTA section plan (essentially repeating invitation to fill the form).
Offer Help on the Form: Sometimes putting a small help link like “Need help? Contact us.” near the form can catch people who might be stuck or have last-minute doubts. This could open a chat or bring them to a contact page. Alternatively, if Arzani has live chat, a chat widget can pop up especially on the form page saying “Have questions? Chat with us while you fill this out.” That can rescue conversions that might otherwise abandon. If doing this, ensure the chat widget doesn’t cover the form fields (place it bottom corner out of the way).
By focusing on form UX in these ways, we ensure that once a user decides to convert, nothing in the form stops them. The mantra is “Don’t make me think” – the form should be intuitive. Many landing page efforts fail not because the user isn’t convinced, but because the final conversion step (the form) is tedious or confusing. We will avoid that trap, keeping the form as a smooth final leg of the journey.
A/B Testing Recommendations
After implementing the landing page with all these best practices, continuous improvement comes from A/B testing (split testing). The idea is to empirically find what actually boosts conversions by testing one variant against another with real traffic. Here’s a plan for A/B testing Arzani’s landing page and what elements to focus on:
Prioritize High-Impact Elements: Not all parts of the page are equal in influence. Based on experience and research, the elements to test first (in order) are:
Headline and Hero Copy: The headline is often a make-or-break element. Test different versions of the headline. For example, Version A (current): “Designed for UK Small Businesses to Buy, Sell, and Scale” vs. Version B: “Sell Your Business 37% Faster with AI-Powered Valuations.” The latter is more specific and benefit-oriented. Or test a pain-focused headline vs. a solution-focused one. You can also test the subheadline or tweak the value proposition phrasing. Keep one version more straightforward, another maybe with a different angle (but still clear). See which yields higher conversion (form submissions). If one clearly outperforms, adopt that style going forward.
CTA Text/Design: We could test “Get My Free Valuation” vs “Get Your Free Valuation” vs “Get Started – Free Valuation”. It’s a minor copy difference, but sometimes one phrasing clicks better with user​
unbounce.com
】. Also, test CTA design aspects like color: e.g., an orange button vs a blue button (ensuring both are high contrast on page). Run that test and see which color draws more clicks. Another test: having the form directly in the hero vs. a button that opens the form. The metric would be overall conversions (completed forms). If embedding the form yields more completed forms (some studies have shown it can), we’d switch to that approach.
Page Length and Depth of Info: Test a long-form page (including all sections as we’ve planned) vs a shorter page that maybe cuts out some content (for instance, remove the detailed feature section and condense benefits, or remove some FAQs). Some audiences respond better to a concise page that gets right to the point, especially if they came from a trusted referral. Others need all the detail and persuasion. You won’t know for sure until you test. Create a shorter variant that still has the essentials: hero, short pain/solution, one testimonial, CTA. If the short version converts nearly as well or better, that’s insight (maybe users don’t need all the detail). If the long version wins, it means those extra sections are providing needed assurance.
Social Proof Emphasis: Test different social proof approaches. For example, Version A: testimonials (as in our page), vs Version B: a more stats/number-driven approach (like a big banner “1,000+ businesses trust Arzani” plus logos, and maybe fewer testimonials). See which resonates more. Alternatively, test presence or absence of a particular testimonial that might be very strong – does adding a specific high-profile testimonial increase conversion?
Imagery: Test the hero image or visual. Version A could have, say, an illustration of people shaking hands on a business deal; Version B might have a screenshot of the Arzani platform/interface. Or A: friendly human image, B: more techy abstract image. This can tell you what kind of visual your audience responds to (emotional human connection vs seeing the product). Keep everything else same while testing image. Similarly, test adding a short explainer video in the hero vs. just static image – sometimes videos increase engagement, other times they distract or slow load. If Arzani can produce a 1-minute intro video, that could be an interesting test (monitor both conversion and engagement metrics).
Form Variations: If using multi-step form, test single-step vs multi-step (does breaking it actually improve completion?). Or test fewer fields vs a version with one extra required field to gauge impact on lead quality vs quantity. For example, test requiring phone number vs making it optional. If requiring phone drops conversion significantly, you might decide to keep it optional or off. If it doesn’t hurt much, requiring it might give you more qualified leads ready for sales follow-up. Always weigh lead quality too – a slightly lower conversion rate might be acceptable if the leads are much more qualified. You can measure quality by looking at how many leads turn into actual sales or serious conversations.
Personalization/Segmentation: If feasible, test separate landing pages for sellers vs buyers vs acquirers. For example, run an ad campaign for “sell your business” that goes to a variant page tailored entirely to sellers (headline: “Sell Your Business…”, content focused on selling), versus the generic combined page. Compare conversion rates between targeted vs generic. If the targeted performs better, it may be worth maintaining multiple versions for different audiences. Tools exist to dynamically swap content based on ad parameters (e.g., using Unbounce’s Dynamic Text Replacement or custom scripts) – you could personalize the headline to say “Sell Your [Industry] Business” if the ad passed an industry parameter, etc. Those advanced tests can significantly boost relevance when done right.
Test One Major Change at a Time: To attribute results, run tests where the two versions differ in one significant aspect. Don’t create completely two different pages with dozens of changes – you won’t know which element caused the difference. For instance, test headline alone (keeping rest same). Then test CTA color separately, etc. An exception is you can test two entirely different design concepts (multivariate), but that’s usually later after testing key pieces. Early on, isolate variables for clarity.
Measure the Right Metrics: The primary metric is conversion rate (form submissions as a percentage of unique visitors). Secondary metrics could be click-through rate on the CTA (for parts of funnel), but ultimately a submitted lead is what matters. If using multi-step, measure how many start vs finish to see if drop-off is at a certain question. Use analytics (like Google Analytics or built-in landing page analytics) to track scroll depth and time on page too: if users aren’t scrolling far, maybe your content arrangement needs adjusting (like important info higher). A/B testing tools (Google Optimize, Optimizely, VWO, etc.) can handle the random traffic split and statistical significance calculation.
Statistical Significance & Traffic: Ensure you run the test long enough to get a significant sample. In B2B, traffic might be lower volume, so be patient. For example, if your baseline conversion is 10% and you want to detect a lift to 12%, you might need a few hundred visitors per variant to be sure. Many A/B testing calculators are available to estimate needed sample. Run tests for at least 1-2 full business cycles (like over different days of week) to account for variability. Don’t stop a test early just because one variant seems ahead – early fluctuations can even out. Aim for 95% confidence level before declaring a winner.
Qualitative Feedback During Testing: Alongside quantitative tests, gather qualitative data. Use a tool for user session recordings or heatmaps (like Hotjar or Crazy Egg) to see where people click or where they may get stuck. Consider a small exit survey: “What stopped you from getting a valuation today?” – this can reveal if a certain objection wasn’t addressed or if the form was too long, etc. This qualitative insight can generate new test ideas. For instance, if many say “I’m just browsing, not ready to sell now,” maybe test adding content that says “Even if you’re not ready to sell yet, a valuation can help you plan” to see if that improves conversions of early-stage visitors.
Test Continuous, but One at a Time: You can have a testing roadmap: first headline, then CTA, then length, etc. Each test can build on the last. When you find a winner, adopt it and then test the next thing on that new version. Over time, you’ll zero in on the most effective combination. Just be careful to reset or account for any seasonality or campaign changes when comparing results. It’s an iterative optimization process.
Don’t Forget to Test Content Tone: We assume professional tone is best (and likely it is for this context). But it could be interesting down the line to test a slightly more conversational or bold tone in copy. Perhaps test a version of the headline that’s more provocative (e.g., “Your Business Is Worth More Than You Think. Find Out How Much – Free.”) versus the baseline. Or test adding humor vs staying formal. These are finer points, but sometimes a touch of personality can differentiate in a sea of bland B2B pages. However, always ensure clarity is not compromised for cleverness unless you have strong reason to believe the clever message resonates bette​
unbounce.com
】. Those kinds of tests make sense once the basics (clarity, structure) are nailed.
Segment Testing: Look at whether different segments behave differently. For example, maybe mobile users convert less – you might A/B test something specifically for mobile (like sticky CTA vs none). Or perhaps traffic from Google Ads vs organic search responds differently – you might run separate experiments for those segments (with tools that allow targeting by referrer or UTM parameters). This way you optimize for each key segment of traffic.
Document and Learn: Keep a record of tests run, results, and insights. Over time you’ll build a knowledge base of what messaging works for Arzani’s audience. For example, you might discover “Pain-focused headlines consistently beat benefit-focused ones for our audience” or “Including industry-specific details improves conversion for niche campaigns.” These learnings inform not just the landing page, but broader marketing strategy and even product messaging.
In essence, treat the landing page as a living project. Launch with best practices (like the ones we’ve compiled) but verify them in the field. CRO (Conversion Rate Optimization) is about empirical improvement. Given Rightbiz is a competitor, presumably Arzani might test elements to outperform whatever Rightbiz is doing. For instance, if Rightbiz’s page has one approach to social proof, Arzani can test an alternative approach to see if it resonates more. Over time, Arzani’s landing page will become finely tuned to its audience, giving it a competitive edge.
